rev.comment: disambiguation link repair ([[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages maintenance|You can help!]])
rev.diff:
Line 53: Line 53:
Following the [[First World War]], the [[Treaty of Versailles]] forced Germany to pay significant reparations (compensation) to the nations that won the war, starting in 1919. However, Germany had a very weak economy at this time: in effect, the young republic of Weimar had no money. To pay its reparations and rebuild the economy, the German government printed money. However, there was no faith in this money, and the hyperinflation began. The inflation reached its peak by November 1923, but ended when a new currency (the [[Rentenmark]]) was introduced. The government stated this new currency had a fixed value, and this was accepted.
Following the [[First World War]], the [[Treaty of Versailles]] forced Germany to pay significant reparations (compensation) to the nations that won the war, starting in 1919. However, Germany had a very weak economy at this time: in effect, the young republic of Weimar had no money. To pay its reparations and rebuild the economy, the German government printed money. However, there was no faith in this money, and the hyperinflation began. The inflation reached its peak by November 1923, but ended when a new currency (the [[Rentenmark]]) was introduced. The government stated this new currency had a fixed value, and this was accepted.
â
Hyperinflation did not directly bring about the [[Nazi]] takeover of Germany; the inflation ended with the introduction of the Rentenmark and the [[Weimar Republic]] continued for a decade afterward. The inflation did, however, call into question the competence of [[liberal]] institutions. It also produced resentment of Germany's bankers and speculators (many of them [[Jewish]]) who were blamed for the inflation.
+
Hyperinflation did not directly bring about the [[Nazi]] takeover of Germany; the inflation ended with the introduction of the Rentenmark and the [[Weimar Republic]] continued for a decade afterward. The inflation did, however, call into question the competence of [[Liberalism|liberal]] institutions. It also produced resentment of Germany's bankers and speculators (many of them [[Jewish]]) who were blamed for the inflation.
[[Image:millionlira.jpg|thumb|right|340px|A 1,000,000 (1 Million) Lira banknote, issued by Turkey. Their currency has been collapsing due to massive printing]]
[[Image:millionlira.jpg|thumb|right|340px|A 1,000,000 (1 Million) Lira banknote, issued by Turkey. Their currency has been collapsing due to massive printing]]
